creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
description: globular body in 8 segments; thin spout; octagonal cover with flower on top; light blue glaze
medium:
Ch'ing-pai ware
Porcelain with pale-blue glaze
text:
Ch'ing-pai (bluish-white) is an apt term for a thin, translucent glaze of a faint, bluish tone that deepens where it thickens or collects in intaglio designs. Ch'ing-pai porcelains are indigenous to southern China; Kiangsi province was the major source and it is likely that kilns in the vicinity of Ching-te-ch'en produced the greatest number and best quality.

This eight-paneled ewer is a fine example of Ch'ing-pai. The refined, delicacy of potting, subtle blue glaze, provide great aesthetic merit. An ewer of nearly identical size and shape was excavated from a Liao tomb in Chao-Yung city, Liaoning province, dated to about 1004.
title: Octagonal Ewer and Cover
